snippet: The government said it would allow foreign retailers who sell just one brand of products to open wholly-owned stores in India, up from a maximum of 51 percent ownership now.
abstract: Indian policy makers change a rule that will make it easier for predominantly single-brand foreign chains like Ikea and Gap to set up stores without taking Indian partners; decision is one of a series of steps officials in India are taking to boost flagging investor confidence and increase the flow of foreign money into the economy.
lead_paragraph: The government said it would allow foreign retailers who sell just one brand of products to open wholly-owned stores in India, up from a maximum of 51 percent ownership now.

headline.main: Rule Change Would Allow Some Foreign-Owned Stores to Open in India
headline.print_headline: Rule Change Would Allow Some Foreign-Owned Stores to Open in India
